choices.C: Modify the static routes to refer both to the next hop and the outgoing interface.
choices.B: Reference the track object 1 on the default route through ISP2 instead of ISP1.
choices.A: Include a valid source-interface keyword in the icmp-echo statement.
choices.D: Modify the threshold to match the administrative distance of the ISP2 route.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. The administrator noticed that the connection was flapping between the two ISPs instead of switching to ISP2 when the ISP1 failed. Which action resolves the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
If you ISP 1 fails the IP SLA will start pinging out via ISP 2. They the IP SLA will start responding again and put the static router back in for ISP 1. This will continue until ISP is back online. 
IP SLA 1
icmp-echo 8.8.8.8 source-interface g1/0

comments.content:
For more control over that, IP SLA may fall back to ISP2 in case source address can reach 8.8.8.8 by another than ISP1. You'll need to control that by adding:
ip route 8.8.8.8 255.255.255.255 g1/0
ip route 8.8.8.8 255.255.255.255 Null0 2
Note this is a bad idea with a common DNS like google. Ideally you ping some WAN specific interface that is only reachable from ISP1 exclusively, it prevents the complexity.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

A is correct

my choice is A
'transport output ssh' is needed to initiate the connection outbound.
-l for username is optional, if the same user is configured on the remote device this flag is not needed

questions.question_text: Which MPLS value is combined with the IP prefix to convert to a VPNv4 prefix?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
Given answer is correct

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: BE
As its name implies, a route distinguisher (RD) distinguishes one set of routes (one VRF) from another. It is a unique number prepended to each route within a VRF to identify it as belonging to that particular VRF or customer. An RD is carried along with a route via MP-BGP when exchanging VPN routes with other PE routers.

https://packetlife.net/blog/2013/jun/10/route-distinguishers-and-route-targets/

comments.content:
A. VPN RT communities are used to identify customer unique routes. --> False

 VPN RD are used to identify customer unique routes. --> True

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
B & E are correct

Selected Answer: BE
B & E are correct

Selected Answer: BE
Correct

choices.B: When the PE redistributes customer routes into MP-BGP, they must be unique.
choices.A: VPN RT communities are used to identify customer unique routes.
choices.E: RD is prepended to each prefix to make routes unique.
choices.D: They are used for a BGP session with the CE device.
choices.C: They are on a CE device to use for static configuration.

questions.question_text:
An engineer configured a leak-map command to summarize EIGRP routes and advertise specifically loopback 0 with an IP of 10.1.1.1 255.255.255.252 along with the summary route. After finishing configuration, the customer complained about not receiving the summary route with the specific loopback address. Which two configurations will fix this issue? (Choose two.)

router eigrp 1
!
route-map Leak-Route deny 10
!
interface Serial 0/0
ip summary-address eigrp 1 10.0.0.0 255.0.0.0 leak-map Leak-Route
